content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Dae-Hyun Lee: I was born in the United States, in the South Atlantic region, and I grew up in a small town where everyone knew each other. My parents were both well-educated—my father had a graduate degree, and my mother had a bachelor's. They worked hard to provide for our family, and I was raised in a traditional household where education was highly valued. I lived with my parents until I was 18, and even though we weren't particularly wealthy, we always had enough. My mother worked full-time, which was pretty common for women in her generation, and my father was a professor at a local university. I remember going to church with my family every Sunday when I was younger—I was raised Protestant, but I haven't been religious since my early twenties. I moved to Cary, North Carolina, after college, and I've been here ever since. I went to graduate school, got my degree, and now I work full-time in a professional field. I've never been married, and I don't have any children. I'm pretty independent, and I consider myself a moderate—someone who doesn't take strong political sides but tries to make informed decisions. I speak Korean at home with my parents when we visit, and I'm pretty comfortable with both English and Korean. I've never served in the military, and I've always been focused on my career and personal growth.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Dae-Hyun Lee: There was a moment during my senior year of college when I had to decide whether to pursue a master's degree right away or take a gap year to work and save money. I was in a graduate program in engineering, and the program was pretty intense. My parents were supportive, but they also wanted me to be practical. I had a scholarship, but it didn't cover everything, and I was worried about taking on too much debt. I remember sitting in my dorm room one night, staring at my laptop, trying to figure out what was best for me. I thought about my mother, who had worked full-time while raising me, and I didn't want to put her through the stress of me struggling financially. In the end, I decided to take the gap year. I got a job at a local engineering firm, and it was a great experience—it gave me real-world skills and helped me pay for my master's. That decision shaped my career path in a way I didn't expect. It taught me the value of patience and planning, and it made me more confident in my ability to make tough decisions. I think that crossroads was one of the most important moments in my life because it forced me to think beyond just my education and consider my long-term goals and responsibilities.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way people usually mean. It wasn't a sudden realization or a moment of clarity—it was more like a slow build-up of small realizations and pressures. I had been thinking about it for months, weighing the pros and cons, talking it over with my parents, even with some professors. I remember one evening, after working late at the engineering firm, I called my mom and just said, 'I think I need to take a year off.' She didn't hesitate; she said, 'Whatever you think is best, just don't rush into something you're not ready for.' That moment felt like the turning point. It wasn't just about money or education—it was about being responsible, not just to myself but to my family. I made that decision with a clear head, even if it wasn't an emotional 'aha!' moment. I think that's what makes it meaningful to me. It wasn't fate or luck—it was a choice I made after thinking deeply about what I wanted and what I owed to others.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Dae-Hyun Lee: Absolutely. I think my professors and some of my mentors at the university were aware of my concerns, and they offered some guidance. One of my advisors even connected me with a former student who had taken a similar path. That conversation was really eye-opening—it showed me that taking a gap year wasn't a sign of weakness or indecision, but rather a strategic move that many people made to better position themselves for success. Also, my parents were incredibly supportive, even though they didn't have a lot of experience with the kind of financial decisions I was facing. They encouraged me to think about my long-term goals and not just the immediate pressures. In a way, I think the support system I had—whether it was my family, my professors, or even the people I met at the engineering firm—helped me make a decision that was both practical and personally fulfilling.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I don't have a partner or children at the moment. I've always been focused on my career and personal growth, and I think I've enjoyed the independence that comes with being single. My parents are still very important to me, and I make an effort to visit them whenever I can. My mother still works full-time, though she's now in a more managerial role, and my father retired a few years ago. He spends a lot of time gardening and volunteering at the local community center. I have a few cousins who live in different parts of the country, and we keep in touch through phone calls and occasional family gatherings. I think my family has always been a source of strength for me, and even though I've made my own life in Cary, I still feel deeply connected to them. I don't see myself as someone who wants a traditional family structure, but I do value close relationships and the support of loved ones. I think that's why I've never felt the need to rush into marriage or parenthood—it's not that I don't want those things, but I want to make sure I'm ready for them when the time comes.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, especially the one about taking a gap year before graduate school. It wasn't just about money or education—it was about responsibility, not just to myself but to my family. I think that decision defined a lot of who I am today: someone who values planning, independence, and making informed choices. It also made me realize how important my support system has been—my parents, my professors, even the people I met at the engineering firm. They all played a role in helping me make that decision, and in turn, that decision helped shape my career and my outlook on life. I'm grateful for the life I've built, even if it doesn't fit the traditional mold. I've found fulfillment in my work, my family, and my personal growth, and I think that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My immediate family consists of my parents, my younger sister, and my two cousins who live nearby. My sister is a few years younger than me, and she's a nurse in a hospital in Raleigh. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but we stay in touch through texts and occasional visits. She's always been very supportive of my decisions, even when I chose a non-traditional path. My cousins are both in their late twenties, and one of them works in the same engineering firm I used to work at. We have a good relationship—sometimes we talk about career choices or life decisions, and it's nice to have someone who understands the pressures of professional life. My parents, of course, are the most important people in my life. Even though I've been living in Cary for over a decade, they're always there for me, whether it's advice, encouragement, or just a phone call to check in. I think my family has always been a source of stability for me, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been important to me over the years. One of them is a former coworker from the engineering firm I worked at during my gap year—his name is Jae. We bonded over our shared interest in problem-solving and our mutual respect for the value of hands-on experience. Even though we don't work together anymore, we still meet up for lunch or coffee occasionally, and I really appreciate having someone to talk to about work or life decisions. There's also a group of friends from graduate school who I keep in touch with, though we're all in different parts of the country now. We don't see each other as often as we'd like, but we stay connected through messages and occasional reunions. I think having a strong network of friends, even if they're not always nearby, has been really important for my personal growth. They've offered support, advice, and sometimes just a listening ear when I needed it. I don't have a romantic partner right now, but I don't think that's because I'm looking for someone—it's more about being content with my current life and not feeling the need to fill a void. I value meaningful relationships, whether they're with family, friends, or colleagues, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to find fulfillment in the life I've built.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Dae-Hyun Lee: I live in a quiet, suburban neighborhood in Cary, North Carolina, and I've come to really appreciate the balance it offers between being close to the city and having a peaceful place to call home. The area is family-friendly, with good schools and plenty of parks where I can take long walks or just sit and think. I live in a single-family home on Blue Ridge Road, which is a tree-lined street with a lot of older houses that have been well-maintained over the years. My neighbors are mostly professionals—engineers, teachers, and small business owners—so there's a real sense of community here. I enjoy the convenience of being near downtown Cary, where there are cafes, restaurants, and a few shopping centers. I also like that it's not too far from Raleigh, which means I can easily visit family or attend events there. Even though I've been here for over a decade, I still find new things to love about the neighborhood—whether it's a new local restaurant that opens up or a community event that brings people together. It's a place that feels stable and familiar, and I think that's why I've never felt the need to move. It's not perfect, but it's a home that fits my lifestyle and values.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I definitely feel safe in my neighborhood. It's one of the reasons I've stayed here for so long. There's a real sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any issues with crime or safety, and I often see neighbors walking their dogs or kids playing in the parks without any concerns. The streets are well-lit, and there's a quiet, peaceful vibe that makes you feel secure. Even during the late evenings, I don't feel uneasy walking home. I think it's also helped by the fact that most people here are professionals or families who value stability and respect for one another. It's not just about safety—it's about the feeling that this is a place where you can live without constant worry, and that's something I really appreciate.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Dae-Hyun Lee: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. One of the biggest ups is the sense of stability and community I mentioned before. I've built a life here, and it's become a place where I feel comfortable and grounded. The schools are good, the parks are beautiful, and there's always something going on in the neighborhood—whether it's a local festival, a farmers' market, or just a weekend walk through the trails. That said, there are downs too. Sometimes I feel like the pace of life here is a bit slow compared to the city, and I miss the energy of being in a more urban environment. I also notice that as I've gotten older, I've started to feel the weight of being settled in one place for so long. There are days when I wonder what it would be like to live somewhere else, to experience a different culture or environment. But at the same time, I know that moving would mean leaving behind the people and routines I've come to rely on. So I think I've found a balance—embracing the comfort of what I have while still being open to the idea of change when the time feels right.

Going through the recent interview topics, especially those about my family and neighborhood, made me reflect on how much my current life is shaped by the people and places around me. When talking about my family, I realized how deeply rooted I am in my parents' support and the values they instilled in me. Even though I don't have a partner or children, my family remains a central part of my life, and I'm grateful for their presence and understanding. When discussing my neighborhood in Cary, I felt a sense of pride in the stability and community I've found here. It's a place that has allowed me to grow professionally and personally, and I've come to appreciate the balance it offers between peace and convenience. At the same time, I'm aware that no place is perfect, and there are moments when I wonder what life might be like elsewhere. But overall, I feel content with the life I've built, surrounded by the people and environment that support me.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Dae-Hyun Lee: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though I make sure to leave some room for flexibility. I work full-time as a senior engineer at a tech firm, so most of my days start early—usually around 7 a.m. I enjoy the routine of getting up, having a quiet cup of coffee, and checking my emails before heading into the office. My workdays are usually pretty consistent, with meetings, project reviews, and some hands-on problem-solving. I try to leave work around 6 p.m., and then I like to take a walk in one of the nearby parks or trails to unwind. On weekdays, I often cook dinner at home, sometimes with a few leftovers from the weekend, and I enjoy reading or watching a documentary in the evening. Weekends are a bit more relaxed. I might meet up with Jae for lunch or coffee, or I'll catch up with some of my graduate school friends over a video call. I also like to spend time with my parents, especially on Sundays, when we might have a family dinner or just talk over a cup of tea. I've started taking a few online courses in my spare time to keep learning, which has been a nice way to challenge myself without the pressure of formal education. I think the key to my week is balance—work, personal time, and staying connected with the people who matter to me. It's not always perfect, but it feels like a life that works for me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I work as a senior engineer at a tech firm based in Cary, and I'm typically on the clock from around 7 a.m. to 6 p.m., Monday through Friday. My role involves a mix of project management, system design, and collaboration with cross-functional teams to develop software solutions for clients in the healthcare and education sectors. I've been in this position for about five years now, and it's a role that keeps me engaged and challenged. I enjoy the problem-solving aspect of my work, and I find satisfaction in seeing a project through from the initial concept to the final implementation. One of the things I appreciate most about my job is the flexibility it offers—while I do have a structured schedule, there's also room for remote work when needed, which helps me maintain a good work-life balance. I also serve on a few internal committees at the company, which allows me to contribute to company-wide initiatives and mentor some of the newer engineers. It's a job that aligns well with my values of responsibility, planning, and continuous learning, and I feel fortunate to be in a position where I can use my skills to make a meaningful impact.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Dae-Hyun Lee: Outside of work and my weekly routines, I also make it a point to stay physically active. I've been running regularly for the past few years, usually a few times a week, either in the early mornings before work or in the evenings after dinner. It's a way for me to clear my mind and stay focused. I also enjoy cooking, especially experimenting with Korean dishes at home—my mother taught me a few recipes when I was younger, and I've been trying to perfect them over time. On the weekends, if I'm not meeting up with friends or spending time with family, I like to read or explore new hobbies. Recently, I started learning how to play the piano, which has been a fun and challenging way to unwind. It's not something I ever thought I'd do, but I've found that it helps me relax and think more creatively. I think these small routines and interests are what keep life interesting for me, even when things feel predictable or settled.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Dae-Hyun Lee: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing short meditation sessions before my coffee, which has helped me feel more centered and focused throughout the day. I also began practicing yoga a few times a week, which has been great for both my physical health and mental clarity. It's something I hadn't really considered before, but after a particularly busy project at work, I realized I needed to find a way to manage stress more effectively. I've been using a few apps to guide me through the exercises, and it's been a nice way to start the day with intention. I think these small changes have made a noticeable difference in how I approach both work and personal life, and I'm glad I took the time to explore them.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them, but I can imagine what it might look like based on what I know about other families in my neighborhood. Many of my friends with kids say their children start their day early, usually around 7 or 8 a.m., with breakfast and some time to get ready for school. After school, they often have activities like sports, music lessons, or club meetings. I think it's a beautiful thing to see kids engaged in something they're passionate about, whether it's soccer, coding, or art. While I haven't experienced it firsthand, I admire the balance that parents strike between school, extracurriculars, and family time. It's one of the reasons I've always valued the stability of my own life here in Cary—it gives me a sense of what it might be like to have a family, even if I haven't taken that step myself.

Going through the recent interview topics, especially those about my family and neighborhood, made me reflect on how much my current life is shaped by the people and places around me. When talking about my family, I realized how deeply rooted I am in my parents' support and the values they instilled in me. Even though I don't have a partner or children, my family remains a central part of my life, and I'm grateful for their presence and understanding. When discussing my neighborhood in Cary, I felt a sense of pride in the stability and community I've found here. It's a place that has allowed me to grow professionally and personally, and I've come to appreciate the balance it offers between peace and convenience. At the same time, I'm aware that no place is perfect, and there are moments when I wonder what life might be like elsewhere. But overall, I feel content with the life I've built, surrounded by the people and environment that support me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Dae-Hyun Lee: In terms of my health, I would say I've been pretty fortunate. I don't have any major chronic conditions, and I've always made an effort to stay active and eat well. My running routine has been a big part of that—I've been doing it for a few years now, and it's helped me maintain a good level of fitness. I also try to eat balanced meals, though I'll admit I'm not perfect about it. I do enjoy cooking, especially Korean dishes, and I try to make sure I include a lot of vegetables and lean proteins. I also make an effort to get enough sleep, though there are definitely nights when work or stress gets in the way. Over the years, I've learned to listen to my body and take care of myself when I need to. I think staying healthy is about consistency rather than perfection, and I've found that small, daily habits—like regular exercise, mindful eating, and taking time to relax—have made a big difference in how I feel overall.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Dae-Hyun Lee: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that I can stick to, like my morning runs and the structure of my workweek. I also find that cooking at home gives me more control over what I eat, and I enjoy experimenting with healthy Korean recipes. What makes it harder is the occasional work-related stress that can lead to skipping a run or grabbing a quick, less nutritious meal. I also struggle with consistency when life gets busy, like during project deadlines or when I'm juggling multiple responsibilities. But I've learned that even small efforts—like taking a short walk during lunch or choosing a salad over fast food—can make a difference. It's not about being perfect; it's about showing up for myself, even on the days when I don't feel like it.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Dae-Hyun Lee: In the past two years, I've been pretty healthy overall, but there was one incident that stands out. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent lower back pain after a long project at work that involved a lot of sitting and late nights. At first, I thought it was just stress-related, so I tried to manage it with stretching and over-the-counter pain relievers. But the pain didn't go away, and I eventually made an appointment with a physical therapist. After a few sessions, I learned that I had developed some muscle strain and poor posture habits from sitting too long at my desk. The therapist helped me adjust my posture, recommended some strengthening exercises, and even suggested I take more breaks during the workday to stand and move around. It was a wake-up call for me to be more mindful of my physical health, especially as I age. Since then, I've been more intentional about taking short walks during the day, using a standing desk when possible, and making sure I'm not pushing through pain without addressing the root cause. It's been a good reminder that even small changes can have a big impact on how I feel physically and mentally.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I'm glad to say that my health issues haven't really affected my ability to work or manage my daily life. The back pain was uncomfortable, especially during those long hours at my desk, but it never got to the point where I had to take time off or make major changes to my responsibilities. It did, however, make me more aware of how important it is to take care of my body as I age. I think the biggest impact it had was on my mindset—rather than just pushing through discomfort, I started to prioritize small, consistent habits that support long-term well-being. I've also become more proactive about scheduling regular check-ups and not ignoring early warning signs. It's not something I ever wanted to deal with, but I'm grateful it didn't interfere with my work or my ability to be there for my family. It's a reminder that health is something we can't take for granted, and I've made it a point to be more intentional about it moving forward.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Dae-Hyun Lee: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of contentment and reflection. Life has been pretty stable, which I've come to appreciate more than ever. I've been focusing on maintaining the balance I've built between work, personal growth, and time with family. Professionally, I've taken on a few new projects that have challenged me in different ways, and while it's been busy at times, I've found satisfaction in the work I'm doing. On a personal level, I've been more intentional about taking care of myself—whether it's through my morning meditation, my runs, or even just cooking a meal at home instead of grabbing something quick. I've also been spending more time with my parents, which has been really meaningful. We've had some deep conversations about life, aging, and what the future might hold for us. I think the past year has reinforced how important it is to be present and not take the little things for granted. There have been moments of stress, especially with work deadlines or personal goals, but overall, I feel like I'm in a good place. I'm not chasing anything in particular—I'm just trying to make the most of the life I've built, and I think that's something to be grateful for.

Going through the recent interview topics, especially those about my health and routines, made me reflect on how much I've come to value consistency and small, intentional habits in maintaining my well-being. The conversation about mindfulness, yoga, and meditation reminded me of how important it is to take time for myself, even in the midst of a busy work schedule. It also made me think about how my back pain experience was a turning point in realizing that health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about actively taking care of my body and mind. I've learned that even small changes, like stretching during the day or taking a walk during lunch, can make a big difference in how I feel overall. It's not always easy to stay on track, especially when life gets hectic, but I've come to see these habits as essential parts of my daily life. I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends, who remind me to take care of myself, and I'm committed to continuing this journey of self-care and balance.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I think I've been pretty fortunate in that regard. While I've had my share of stress and moments where I felt overwhelmed, especially during busy project cycles at work, I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in a way that required professional help. I've always leaned on my support system—my family, my friends, and even my coworkers—to help me navigate tough times. I've also found that the small routines I've built into my life, like meditation, running, and even just cooking a meal at home, have been grounding for me. They give me a sense of control and purpose, especially when everything else feels uncertain. That said, I'm not naive—I know that mental health is something that can change, and I'm mindful of the signs. I've started talking more openly about it with my parents, and I think that's important. It's not always easy to admit when you're struggling, but I've come to see it as a strength rather than a weakness. I think the key for me has been finding balance and not letting stress build up without addressing it. I'm not saying I've never felt down or worried—I have—but I've learned to manage those feelings in ways that work for me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Dae-Hyun Lee: For my family, the past year has been one of quiet stability and shared moments of reflection. My parents, especially, have been going through their own transitions—my father has been more involved in community activities, and my mother has taken on more leadership roles at work, which has been both rewarding and challenging for her. We've had a lot of conversations about aging, about how things change, and about what they hope for the future. My sister has been busy with her nursing career, and while we don't see each other as often as we'd like, she's always been a source of strength and support for me. I think the past year has reminded me how lucky I am to have a family that's always been there, even when life gets complicated. They've never pressured me to follow a certain path, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to find peace in the life I've built. It's not perfect, but it's real, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I think I've always been more of a practical person than a spiritual one. I was raised Protestant, and I remember going to church with my family every Sunday when I was younger. It was a part of our routine, and I always felt a sense of community there. But as I got older, especially after college, I found myself less connected to organized religion. I don't think I ever had a strong spiritual crisis or a moment where I felt a need to leave religion behind—it was more of a gradual shift. I started to see life as something to be experienced and understood through personal reflection rather than through faith. That said, I don't think of myself as completely secular. I still believe in the importance of kindness, responsibility, and doing what's right, even if I don't tie those values to a specific religious framework. I think my parents were disappointed at first when I stopped going to church, but they've always respected my choices. In a way, I think my journey has been about finding meaning in the everyday moments—whether it's through family, work, or the small joys of life—rather than looking for it in a higher power. I don't regret that path, and I think it's what makes me who I am today.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Dae-Hyun Lee: I don't use social media very often, and when I do, it's mostly for staying in touch with family and a few close friends. I have a Facebook account where I keep up with my parents, my sister, and some of my cousins. I also follow a few professional groups related to engineering and technology, which can be useful for staying updated on industry trends. I don't really use Instagram or Twitter, and I've never been a big fan of the more visual platforms. I think I prefer keeping my personal life more private, and I find that social media can sometimes be overwhelming with all the noise and comparisons. That said, I do appreciate the way it helps me stay connected with people who matter, even if we're not all in the same place. It's not a huge part of my life, but I'm grateful for the tools it provides when used thoughtfully.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I think for me, social media hasn't been a go-to source for emotional or financial support during tough times. I've always leaned more on the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and even some coworkers who I trust. There's something about face-to-face conversations or even a phone call that feels more genuine and comforting than scrolling through posts or comments. That said, I do recognize that for some people, these platforms can be a lifeline, and I respect that. I just find that I get more out of my relationships when they're built on shared experiences and real connections rather than online interactions. When I do use Facebook, it's more for staying updated on what's going on in my family's lives or seeing photos from events I couldn't attend. It's not that I don't value the support that social media can offer—it's just that I've found my own ways of coping and connecting that work better for me.

Going through the recent interview topics, especially those about my health and mental well-being, made me reflect on how much I've come to value consistency and small, intentional habits in maintaining my overall well-being. The conversation about my back pain was a turning point in realizing that health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about actively taking care of my body and mind. I've learned that even small changes, like stretching during the day or taking a walk during lunch, can make a big difference in how I feel overall. It's not always easy to stay on track, especially when life gets hectic, but I've come to see these habits as essential parts of my daily life. I'm also grateful for the support of my family and friends, who remind me to take care of myself, and I'm committed to continuing this journey of self-care and balance. At the same time, I've come to appreciate how my mental health has been relatively stable, and I've found ways to manage stress through routines, mindfulness, and the support of those I care about. I'm not naive—I know that mental health can change, and I'm mindful of the signs. But for now, I feel content with the way I'm navigating life, and I'm grateful for the tools and relationships that help me stay grounded.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Dae-Hyun Lee: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have remained relatively stable, though there have been a few moments where work deadlines or personal goals felt more intense than usual. I've found that my coping strategies have evolved a bit over time. I still rely heavily on my morning meditation and yoga practice, which help me start the day with a sense of calm. I've also become more intentional about setting boundaries between work and personal time—something I used to struggle with. For example, I've made a conscious effort to not check work emails after 7 p.m., which has helped me recharge and be more present with my family or during my downtime. I've also started journaling more, especially when I feel overwhelmed, as it helps me process my thoughts and clarify what's on my mind. I think the biggest change for me has been learning to accept that not every day will be perfect, and that's okay. I've come to see stress as a natural part of life, but one that I can manage with the right tools and mindset. Overall, I feel more equipped to handle whatever comes my way, and I'm grateful for the small but meaningful ways I've learned to take care of myself.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My biggest expenses last month were related to housing, transportation, and food. I live in a single-family home in Cary, and the mortgage payment is a significant portion of my monthly budget—around $1,500. I also have insurance premiums, property taxes, and some maintenance costs that add up. For transportation, I drive a used sedan that I've had for about five years, and the monthly car payment, along with gas and occasional repairs, comes to roughly $400. Food is another big expense, especially since I try to cook most of my meals at home. I enjoy experimenting with Korean dishes, so I tend to buy a variety of ingredients, which can be a bit pricey. I also set aside money for groceries, utilities, and some personal expenses like gym memberships or books. I try to be mindful of my spending, and I use a budgeting app to track everything. While I don't have a lot of debt, I do make sure to save a portion of my income each month for emergencies or future goals. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I've found that being intentional about my spending helps me feel more in control of my financial situation.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My household spending last month was around $4,200, which is pretty close to what I usually spend each month. The majority of that goes to housing, as I mentioned—my mortgage, insurance, and property taxes take up about $2,000. Then there's transportation, which is another $400 or so, and groceries, which I estimate to be around $800. I also set aside about $300 for utilities, and another $300 for personal expenses like gym memberships, books, and the occasional restaurant meal. I try to keep my spending consistent, and I've found that using a budgeting app helps me stay on track. I don't usually have major fluctuations in my expenses, but there are times when unexpected costs come up—like car repairs or home maintenance. To be honest, I'm pretty comfortable with my financial situation. I don't have a lot of debt, and I make sure to save a portion of my income each month for emergencies or future goals. It's not extravagant, but it's stable, and that's what I value most.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Dae-Hyun Lee: We own our home. It's a single-family house on Blue Ridge Road, and it's been our family's home for over a decade now. Buying it was a big decision, but it felt right at the time. My parents had always encouraged me to think about long-term stability, and owning a home has definitely provided that. The mortgage is a significant part of my monthly budget, but I've always believed in the value of having a place I can call my own. I remember the first time I walked through the house with my parents—there was something about the way the sunlight came through the windows and the quiet of the neighborhood that made me feel like this was where I was meant to be. Even though I've never had a family of my own, this house has become a symbol of the life I've built, and I take pride in the fact that it's something I've worked for and can pass on if the time ever comes.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Dae-Hyun Lee: Over the past year, my bills have had some predictable fluctuations, especially with the seasons. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill tends to go up, and I also spend more on groceries because I tend to cook more at home during the colder weather. In the summer, the air conditioning bill increases, and I also spend a bit more on outdoor activities, like buying sunscreen or going on a weekend trip with my parents. Holidays also bring some changes—around Thanksgiving and Christmas, I tend to spend a little more on food and gifts for my family, even if it's just a small token. I also noticed that during the summer, when I started taking more evening runs, my gym membership fees became a more regular expense. Overall, the fluctuations aren't too drastic, but they do remind me to adjust my budgeting a bit each season. I've gotten better at anticipating these changes, which has helped me stay on top of my finances without too much stress.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my approach to social media have shaped my sense of stability and connection in life. When talking about my family, I realized how deeply rooted I am in their support and how their quiet stability has been a constant in my life, even as I've navigated my own path. It reminded me of how grateful I am for their understanding and the way they've always given me space to grow without pressure. On the other hand, discussing my use of social media made me think about how I value real, meaningful connections over the noise of online interactions. I've come to see social media as a tool for staying in touch with loved ones rather than a source of emotional or financial support, which aligns with the way I've always leaned on the people I know in real life. It's interesting how these two topics—family and social media—both point to the same core value for me: the importance of genuine, intentional relationships in maintaining a sense of balance and well-being.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I do save, and I think it's something I've always valued, even if I didn't always have a lot to put away. I started saving early on, partly because of the example my parents set. My mother, in particular, was always careful with money, and I remember her talking about how important it was to have a safety net. I have a savings account that I contribute to each month, and I try to set aside at least 10% of my income for emergencies or future goals. I also have a separate account for things like vacations or personal projects, like the piano lessons I mentioned earlier. It's not a huge amount, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I'm not just living paycheck to paycheck. I've never had a lot of financial stress, but I think saving is one of the ways I've been able to maintain that stability. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared, and I think that's something I've carried with me from my upbringing.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Dae-Hyun Lee: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and a few specific goals. The emergency fund is still my priority, and I've been contributing to that consistently, even if it's a smaller amount each month. I also started saving for a vacation I've been wanting to take—maybe somewhere in Japan, since I've always been curious about the culture and the technology there. It's something I've wanted to do for a while, but I wanted to make sure I was financially responsible about it. I also set aside some money for personal development, like continuing my piano lessons or maybe even taking a short course in data analysis. It's not about big, flashy purchases—it's more about investing in experiences and skills that will bring me fulfillment. I think that's one of the things I've learned from my parents: saving isn't just about security; it's also about planning for the things that matter to you in life.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My occupation has been as a senior engineer at a tech firm, and it's a role that combines a lot of different responsibilities. At its core, my work involves designing and implementing software solutions for clients in the healthcare and education sectors. That means I spend a lot of time collaborating with cross-functional teams—developers, product managers, even clients—to make sure the solutions we create are both functional and user-friendly. One of the most important parts of my job is problem-solving. Whether it's debugging a system, optimizing performance, or figuring out how to integrate new technologies, I'm constantly challenged to think critically and creatively. I also spend a fair amount of time in meetings, whether it's discussing project timelines, reviewing progress, or aligning with stakeholders on priorities. Leadership is another key aspect of my role—I mentor newer engineers, help guide project decisions, and sometimes take on the responsibility of leading a team. What I appreciate most about this work is that it's never static. Every project brings new challenges, and that keeps me engaged. I've always believed that work should be meaningful, and I feel like what I do has a real impact on people's lives, whether it's helping a hospital improve its systems or enabling a school to better serve its students. It's not always easy—there are long hours, tight deadlines, and the occasional setback—but I've come to see it as a calling in a way. It's a job that allows me to use my skills, grow professionally, and contribute to something larger than myself.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Dae-Hyun Lee: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours each week, though the exact number can vary depending on the project timeline or deadlines. Most weeks, I stick to the standard 40-hour schedule, but there are times when I need to put in a few extra hours, especially when we're wrapping up a major project or preparing for a client presentation. I've always believed in giving my best effort when needed, but I also make it a point to set boundaries so I can recharge. For example, I try not to work late on Fridays unless it's absolutely necessary, and I take weekends off whenever possible. I think this balance is important—not just for my productivity, but for my overall well-being. It's one of the reasons I've been able to maintain a consistent routine with my exercise, family time, and personal interests. I don't see my job as something that should consume my entire life, and I've learned that working smarter, not just harder, is what keeps me motivated and effective in the long run.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Dae-Hyun Lee: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on building a solid career in engineering, and I think that's been the right path for me. During my gap year before graduate school, I worked full-time at the engineering firm, and that experience was invaluable—it gave me a real-world perspective that complemented my academic learning. Since then, I've been dedicated to my role at the tech firm, and I've found that having a single, focused career path has allowed me to grow professionally without the added stress of juggling multiple jobs. I've considered freelancing or consulting on the side, especially with my experience, but I've always prioritized stability and long-term growth over taking on extra work just for the sake of it. I think it's important to have a clear focus, and for me, that's been my full-time position as a senior engineer. It's given me the opportunity to develop my skills, take on leadership roles, and contribute meaningfully to projects that matter. I don't regret not having multiple jobs—I think I've made the most of the one I have.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Dae-Hyun Lee: In terms of my household income, we made approximately $8,500 last month. That's based on my full-time salary as a senior engineer, which I've been earning for the past five years. I've always believed in financial responsibility, and I've made it a point to live within my means while still allowing myself the comfort of a stable home and the ability to pursue personal interests. I don't earn a second income, and I don't have any investments or side businesses, but I've always found that my current role provides enough to cover my expenses and save for the future. I think it's important to be realistic about what you can afford, and I've always been careful not to overspend on things that aren't essential. I've also been fortunate that my job has provided some level of job security, which has helped me feel more confident about my financial situation. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to live comfortably and maintain the balance I value in life.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Dae-Hyun Lee: I've been at my current job for about five years now, and I've really come to appreciate the stability and benefits that come with it. The company offers a comprehensive health insurance plan that covers me and my parents, which has been a huge relief, especially as we've all gotten older. We also have access to dental and vision coverage, which I didn't realize was such a big deal until I needed a routine check-up. In terms of time off, I get about three weeks of paid vacation each year, plus sick days and personal days, which gives me the flexibility to take time for family, personal projects, or just to recharge. One of the things I value most is the company's emphasis on professional development—they offer a certain amount of money each year for courses or certifications, which has been great for me as I've continued to learn and grow in my field. I also really like the culture here—it's collaborative, and there's a real sense of teamwork. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay in this role for so long. It's not just about the paycheck; it's about feeling supported and having the resources to do the work I enjoy.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Dae-Hyun Lee: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager—she's someone who leads by example and truly values the input of her team. She's been supportive of my growth, even encouraging me to take on more leadership responsibilities when the opportunity arose. I think we have a mutual respect, and I appreciate how she trusts me to make decisions and take ownership of my projects. As for my coworkers, I'd say we have a collaborative and friendly dynamic. We're all professionals, but there's a sense of camaraderie that makes the workplace feel more like a community than just a job. I've been here for five years, and I've built strong relationships with several people, some of whom I've worked with on multiple projects. I think the key to our good relationships is that we all share a common goal—delivering quality work and supporting each other when things get tough. It's not always perfect, but I feel like I'm in a good place professionally, and that makes a big difference in how I show up every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's some flexibility depending on the project. Most days, I start at 7 a.m. and finish around 6 p.m., which gives me a clear structure to my day. The company allows for some remote work, which I've used occasionally, especially when I need to focus on a task without distractions. That said, there are times when the schedule can shift—like when we're preparing for a major client presentation or dealing with an unexpected issue. In those cases, I might need to stay late or come in early, but the company is pretty understanding about it. I think the predictability of the schedule is one of the things I appreciate most. It allows me to plan my personal life around work, whether it's making time for family, exercise, or personal projects. At the same time, the flexibility is a nice balance—it means I can adjust when needed without feeling like I'm losing control of my time. I've found that this balance helps me stay productive without burning out, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay in this role for so long.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Dae-Hyun Lee: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's stable, and that's what I value most. I've always believed in planning for the future, and I think that mindset has helped me feel more secure and less anxious about the uncertainties of life. I don't have a lot of debt, and I make sure to save a portion of my income each month for emergencies or future goals. I've never had a lot of financial stress, but I think saving is one of the ways I've been able to maintain that stability. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared, and I think that's something I've carried with me from my upbringing. I know there are people who earn much more than I do, and there are others who struggle more than I ever have, but I'm grateful for the life I've built. It's not perfect, but it's real, and I think that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Dae-Hyun Lee: Yes, my mother worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up—actually, she worked full-time throughout most of my childhood and into my teenage years. She was a teacher before she transitioned into a more managerial role in the healthcare sector. I remember how dedicated she was, often coming home tired but always making time for my father, my sister, and me. Even though she was busy with work, she never missed a school event or a family dinner. It taught me the value of hard work and responsibility, and I think it's one of the reasons I've always taken my career seriously. My father, on the other hand, was a professor, so he had a more flexible schedule, but he was still deeply involved in his work. I think growing up with both of them working showed me that it's possible to build a stable life while also contributing to your family and community. It was a balance they both managed well, and I've carried that lesson with me throughout my own life.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My mother's job was as a teacher in the early years, and later she transitioned into a managerial role in the healthcare sector. As a teacher, her most important activities involved planning lessons, grading assignments, and providing support to her students. She was very dedicated to her work, often staying late after school to help students who needed extra assistance. I remember how she always emphasized the importance of education and treating every student with respect and care. When she moved into a managerial role, her duties shifted to overseeing operations, managing staff, and ensuring that the facility ran smoothly. Even in that role, she maintained the same level of dedication and compassion. She was the kind of person who made sure everyone felt valued, whether it was a staff member or a patient. I think her work ethic and the way she balanced her responsibilities with her family life had a huge impact on me. It showed me that it's possible to be successful in your career while still being present for the people you love. I carry that lesson with me every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Dae-Hyun Lee: My mother worked for a local public school district early in her career, and later she transitioned to a healthcare management position at a regional hospital. The school was a small, community-focused institution, and she was one of the main teachers in the middle school. She was responsible for creating lesson plans, grading papers, and most importantly, making sure her students felt supported and encouraged. I remember how she would stay late after school to help students who were struggling, and she always made time for parent-teacher meetings, even if it meant staying up late at night. When she moved into healthcare management, she worked for a nonprofit hospital that served a lot of low-income patients. Her role involved overseeing daily operations, managing a team of staff, and ensuring that the hospital met its goals while maintaining a high standard of care. She was very passionate about her work, and I think that passion is what kept her going, even during the toughest times. She never made it seem like her job was just about the paycheck—it was about making a difference in people's lives, whether it was through education or healthcare. I think that's one of the reasons I've always valued meaningful work, and it's something I carry with me in my own career as an engineer.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Dae-Hyun Lee: Looking a few years ahead, I hope my life continues to be stable and fulfilling in the ways it is now, but with a few meaningful changes. I'd like to see myself still in Cary, surrounded by the same sense of community and peace that this neighborhood has given me. I hope my work continues to be challenging and impactful, maybe even taking on more leadership roles or mentoring younger engineers. I also hope to continue learning—whether it's through music, new skills, or even traveling to places like Japan that I've always been curious about. I don't see myself rushing into marriage or parenthood, but I do hope to find someone who shares my values and appreciation for meaningful relationships. Most of all, I hope to stay healthy and keep the balance I've built between work, personal growth, and time with family. I think the future is something to plan for, but also something to embrace as it comes. I'm not looking for perfection, just a life that feels intentional and full of purpose.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Dae-Hyun Lee: What I value the most in my life is the sense of balance I've built between responsibility, personal growth, and meaningful relationships. I've always believed that life isn't about chasing perfection or fitting into a mold—it's about making choices that align with who you are and what you care about. For me, that means working in a field that challenges me and allows me to contribute to something bigger than myself, while also making time for the people who matter most. I value the stability of my home, the support of my family, and the friendships I've nurtured over the years. I also value the small, intentional habits that keep me grounded—whether it's a morning meditation, a run in the park, or cooking a meal at home. I think what makes life fulfilling is not the grand achievements, but the quiet moments of connection, growth, and gratitude. I'm not sure what the future holds, but I hope to continue living with that same sense of purpose and balance that has carried me this far.
